CSS Fundamentals:
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) defines how HTML elements look and feel in a web page. This chapter teaches layout, styling, units, animations, and responsive design.

1. What is CSS?
CSS controls colors, spacing, fonts, layout, and animations. It is applied inline, internally in <style> tags, or externally using a .css file.

2. Selectors:
CSS selectors target elements using tag names, classes, IDs, attributes, pseudo-classes (:hover, :focus), and pseudo-elements (::before, ::after).

3. Box Model:
Each HTML element is a box with content, padding, border, and margin. Understanding this model is essential for spacing and layouts.

4. Colors, Typography & Backgrounds:
Control text styles, fonts, sizes, line heights, background colors, gradients, and background images.

5. Display Property:
Defines how elements behave: block (full width), inline (no new line), inline-block, flex, grid, or none.

6. Flexbox:
A modern layout system for centering and aligning items. Properties include justify-content, align-items, flex-direction, flex-wrap, gap.

7. CSS Grid:
Two-dimensional layout system with rows and columns. Use grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows, and gap to build responsive grids.

8. CSS Units:
Includes px, %, em, rem, vh, vw. Relative units enable responsive designs.

9. Transitions & Animations:
Transitions animate property changes smoothly. Keyframes create animations that run over time.

10. CSS Variables:
Use custom properties like --primary to create themeable and reusable styles.

11. Positioning:
Control element placement using static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky positioning.

12. Responsive Design:
Use media queries, mobile-first layouts, and flexible units to ensure the website adapts to all screen sizes.

By the end of this chapter, you will be confident in creating modern, responsive, and visually appealing designs using CSS.
JavaScript Essentials:
JavaScript is the programming language of the web, used to create interactive and dynamic behavior in websites. This chapter covers variables, data types, operators, functions, loops, arrays, objects, ES6 features, and asynchronous programming.

1. Introduction to JavaScript:
JavaScript runs in the browser and controls interactivity like animations, form validation, popups, and dynamic UI updates. It is also used on servers through Node.js.

2. Variables:
var (older and function scoped), let (block scoped), and const (block scoped and non-reassignable). Modern JavaScript uses let and const.

3. Data Types:
Primitive types include string, number, boolean, null, undefined, symbol, bigint. Reference types include objects, arrays, and functions.

4. Operators:
Includes arithmetic (+, -, *, /), comparison (==, ===, !=, >, <), logical (&&, ||, !), and string operators.

5. Functions:
Regular and arrow functions allow reusable blocks of code. Arrow functions provide cleaner syntax.

6. Conditionals:
Control flow using if, else if, else, and switch to handle multiple logical cases.

7. Loops:
Repeat actions using for, while, do-while, and array methods like forEach.

8. Arrays & Methods:
Arrays store lists of items. Common methods include push, pop, map, filter, reduce, and forEach.

9. Objects:
Objects store key-value data and methods. Access properties with dot notation or bracket notation.

10. Template Literals:
Use backticks to insert variables inside strings: `Hello, ${name}`.

11. ES6 Features:
Includes arrow functions, template literals, spread operator, destructuring, classes, let/const.

12. Promises & Async/Await:
Handle asynchronous operations like fetching data from APIs using .then() or async/await.

13. Error Handling:
Use try...catch to capture runtime errors and prevent crashes.

14. Intro to DOM Manipulation:
Use querySelector, innerHTML, and style properties to modify the webpage dynamically.

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to write clean, modern JavaScript and understand how dynamic web pages are built.
DOM Manipulation:
The Document Object Model (DOM) is the interface that represents your webpage as a tree of elements. With DOM manipulation, JavaScript can change HTML, update styles, add new elements, remove elements, and respond to user actions.

1. What is the DOM?
The DOM represents each HTML element as an object. JavaScript can access, modify, and interact with this structure to create dynamic behavior.

2. Selecting Elements:
Use querySelector, querySelectorAll, getElementById, getElementsByClassName, and getElementsByTagName to target elements.

3. Changing Text & HTML:
Use innerText, textContent, and innerHTML to update the content of elements. innerHTML replaces entire HTML blocks.

4. Styling Elements:
Modify styles with element.style or use classList to add, remove, and toggle CSS classes.

5. Creating Elements:
Use document.createElement to create a new node, then appendChild or append to insert it into the DOM.

6. Removing Elements:
Call element.remove() or parent.removeChild(child) to delete elements dynamically.

7. Event Handling:
Listen for user interactions using addEventListener. Common events include click, input, submit, keydown, and scroll.

8. Event Bubbling & Capturing:
Events flow from parent to child (capturing) and child to parent (bubbling). Use stopPropagation to stop the event chain.

9. Working with Forms:
Read input values using input.value, validate fields, and prevent default form submission using e.preventDefault().

10. Attributes & Properties:
Use getAttribute, setAttribute, and removeAttribute. Access properties like checked, value, and placeholder.

11. DOM Traversal:
Use parentElement, children, nextElementSibling, and previousElementSibling to navigate the DOM.

12. Cloning & Templates:
Clone existing nodes using cloneNode(true) to duplicate UI components like cards or messages.

13. Fetch & Update DOM:
Call APIs with fetch, then update DOM elements based on the response.

14. Best Practices:
Use classList for styling, avoid heavy DOM queries, use event delegation, and avoid unsafe innerHTML.

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to dynamically update your UI, handle events, build interactive pages, and understand how modern frontend frameworks manipulate the DOM internally.
